sn52.8:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā anuruddho sāvatthiyaṃ viharati salaḷāgāre.
sn52.8:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Anuruddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the frankincense-tree hut.

sn52.8:1.2.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā anuruddho bhikkhū āmantesi …pe… etadavoca:
sn52.8:1.2.eng: There Venerable Anuruddha addressed the mendicants:

sn52.8:1.3.pli: “seyyathāpi, āvuso, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā.
sn52.8:1.3.eng: “Reverends, suppose that, although the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east,

sn52.8:1.4.eng: a large crowd were to come along with a spade and basket, saying:

sn52.8:1.5.pli: ‘mayaṃ imaṃ gaṅgānadiṃ pacchāninnaṃ karissāma pacchāpoṇaṃ pacchāpabbhāran’ti.
sn52.8:1.5.eng: ‘We’ll make this Ganges river slant, slope, and incline to the west!’

sn52.8:1.6.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññathāvuso, api nu so mahājanakāyo gaṅgānadiṃ pacchāninnaṃ kareyya pacchāpoṇaṃ pacchāpabbhāran”ti?
sn52.8:1.6.eng: What do you think, reverends? Would they succeed?”

sn52.8:1.9.eng: The Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn52.8:1.10.pli: Sā na sukarā pacchāninnaṃ kātuṃ pacchāpoṇaṃ pacchāpabbhāraṃ.
sn52.8:1.10.eng: It’s not easy to make it slant, slope, and incline to the west.

sn52.8:1.11.pli: Yāvadeva ca pana so mahājanakāyo kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
sn52.8:1.11.eng: That large crowd will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

sn52.8:2.1.pli: “Evameva kho, āvuso, bhikkhuṃ cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāventaṃ cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkarontaṃ rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā bhogehi abhihaṭṭhuṃ pavāreyyuṃ:
sn52.8:2.1.eng: “In the same way, while a mendicant develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, if rulers or their chief ministers, friends or colleagues, relatives or family should invite them to accept wealth, saying:

sn52.8:2.2.pli: ‘ehambho purisa, kiṃ te ime kāsāvā anudahanti?
sn52.8:2.2.eng: ‘Please, worthy man, why let these ocher robes torment you?

sn52.8:2.3.eng: Why follow the practice of shaving your head and carrying an alms bowl?

sn52.8:2.4.pli: Ehi hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjassu puññāni ca karohī’ti.
sn52.8:2.4.eng: Come, return to a lesser life, enjoy wealth, and make merit!’

sn52.8:3.1.pli: So vata, āvuso, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāvento cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkaronto sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn52.8:3.1.eng: It is quite impossible for a mendicant who is developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation to resign the training and return to a lesser life.

sn52.8:3.3.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, cittaṃ dīgharattaṃ vivekaninnaṃ vivekapoṇaṃ vivekapabbhāraṃ taṃ vata hīnāyāvattissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn52.8:3.3.eng: Because for a long time that mendicant’s mind has slanted, sloped, and inclined to seclusion. So it’s impossible for them to return to a lesser life.

sn52.8:3.4.pli: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāveti, cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkarotīti?
sn52.8:3.4.eng: And how does a mendicant develop and cultivate the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?

sn52.8:3.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body …

sn52.8:3.8.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.8:3.8.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.8:3.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāveti, cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkarotī”ti.
sn52.8:3.9.eng: That’s how a mendicant develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn52.9:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca sāriputto vesāliyaṃ viharanti ambapālivane.
sn52.9:1.1.eng: At one time the venerables Anuruddha and Sāriputta were staying near Vesālī, in Ambapālī’s Mango Grove.

sn52.9:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:
sn52.9:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Anuruddha, and said to him:

sn52.9:2.1.pli: “Vippasannāni kho te, āvuso anuruddha, indriyāni, parisuddho mukhavaṇṇo pariyodāto.
sn52.9:2.1.eng: “Reverend Anuruddha, your faculties are so very clear, and your complexion is pure and bright.

sn52.9:2.2.pli: Katamenāyasmā anuruddho vihārena etarahi bahulaṃ viharatī”ti?
sn52.9:2.2.eng: What kind of meditation are you usually practicing these days?”

sn52.9:2.3.pli: “Catūsu khvāhaṃ, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto etarahi bahulaṃ viharāmi.
sn52.9:2.3.eng: “These days, reverend, I usually meditate with my mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn52.9:2.5.pli: Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, kāye kāyānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn52.9:2.5.eng: I meditate observing an aspect of the body …

sn52.9:2.8.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
sn52.9:2.8.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.9:2.9.pli: imesu khvāhaṃ, āvuso, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto etarahi bahulaṃ viharāmi.
sn52.9:2.9.eng: These days I usually meditate with my mind firmly established in these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn52.9:2.10.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, so imesu catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto bahulaṃ viharatī”ti.
sn52.9:2.10.eng: A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—usually meditates with their mind firmly established in these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn52.9:3.1.pli: “Lābhā vata no, āvuso, suladdhaṃ vata no, āvuso.
sn52.9:3.1.eng: “We’re so fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate,

sn52.9:3.2.pli: Ye mayaṃ āyasmato anuruddhassa sammukhāva assumha āsabhiṃ vācaṃ bhāsamānassā”ti.
sn52.9:3.2.eng: to have heard such a dramatic statement in the presence of Venerable Anuruddha.”

sn53.1-12:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn53.1-12:1.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn53.1-12:1.6.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn53.1-12:1.6.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn53.1-12:1.7.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn53.1-12:1.7.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

sn53.1-12:1.8.pli: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn53.1-12:1.8.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

sn53.1-12:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn53.1-12:2.1.eng: The Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn53.1-12:2.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro jhāne bhāvento cattāro jhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn53.1-12:2.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four absorptions slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn53.1-12:2.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro jhāne bhāvento cattāro jhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
sn53.1-12:2.3.eng: And how does a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four absorptions slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

sn53.1-12:2.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn53.1-12:2.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn53.1-12:2.5.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …

sn53.1-12:2.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro jhāne bhāvento cattāro jhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn53.1-12:2.8.eng: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four absorptions slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn53.1-12:3.1.eng: Six on slanting to the east,

sn53.1-12:3.2.eng: and six on slanting to the ocean;

sn53.1-12:3.4.eng: and that’s how this chapter is recited.

sn53.13-22:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in the chapter on diligence at SN 45.139–148.)

sn53.13-22:2.1.eng: The Realized One, footprint, roof peak,

sn53.23-34:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in the chapter on hard work at SN 45.149–160.)

sn53.23-34:2.2.eng: a tree, a pot, and a spike,

sn53.23-34:2.3.eng: the atmosphere, and two on clouds,

sn53.23-34:2.4.eng: a ship, a guest house, and a river.

sn53.35-44:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in the chapter on searches at SN 45.161–170.)

sn53.35-44:2.2.eng: states of existence, three kinds of suffering,

sn53.45-54:1.3.eng: Desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.

sn53.45-54:1.4.eng: These are the five higher fetters.

sn53.45-54:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya cattāro jhānā bhāvetabbā.
sn53.45-54:1.5.eng: The four absorptions should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

sn53.45-54:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn53.45-54:1.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn53.45-54:1.8.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe…
sn53.45-54:1.8.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …

sn53.45-54:1.11.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ime cattāro jhānā bhāvetabbā”ti vitthāretabbaṃ.
sn53.45-54:1.11.eng: These four absorptions should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.”

sn53.45-54:1.12.eng: (Tell in full as in the Linked Discourses on the Path at SN 45.171–180.)

sn53.45-54:2.4.eng: aggregates, and fetters high and low.

sn53.45-54:2.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on Absorption are the ninth section.

sn54.1:1.3.pli: “ekadhammo, bhikkhave, bhāvito bahulīkato mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso.
sn54.1:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, when one thing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

sn54.1:1.6.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, bhikkhave, ānāpānassati kathaṃ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā?
sn54.1:1.6.eng: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?

sn54.1:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
sn54.1:1.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.

sn54.1:1.8.eng: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.

sn54.1:2.1.pli: Dīghaṃ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṃ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
sn54.1:2.1.eng: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’

sn54.1:2.2.pli: rassaṃ vā assasanto ‘rassaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṃ vā passasanto ‘rassaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
sn54.1:2.2.eng: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’

sn54.1:2.3.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’

sn54.1:2.4.pli: ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
sn54.1:2.4.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’

sn54.1:3.1.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing rapture.’

sn54.1:3.2.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing bliss.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing bliss.’

sn54.1:3.3.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mental process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mental process.’

sn54.1:3.4.pli: ‘passambhayaṃ cittasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṃ cittasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
sn54.1:3.4.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the mental process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the mental process.’

sn54.1:4.1.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mind.’

sn54.1:4.2.pli: ‘abhippamodayaṃ cittaṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘abhippamodayaṃ cittaṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati;
sn54.1:4.2.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in gladdening the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out gladdening the mind.’

sn54.1:4.3.pli: ‘samādahaṃ cittaṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘samādahaṃ cittaṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati;
sn54.1:4.3.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in immersing the mind in samādhi.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out immersing the mind in samādhi.’

sn54.1:4.4.pli: ‘vimocayaṃ cittaṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘vimocayaṃ cittaṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati;
sn54.1:4.4.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in freeing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out freeing the mind.’

sn54.1:4.5.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing impermanence.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing impermanence.’

sn54.1:5.2.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing fading away.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing fading away.’

sn54.1:5.3.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing cessation.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing cessation.’

sn54.1:5.4.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’

sn54.1:6.1.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, bhikkhave, ānāpānassati evaṃ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā”ti.
sn54.1:6.1.eng: Mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial.”

sn54.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kimilāyaṃ viharati veḷuvane.
sn54.10:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kimbilā in the Freshwater Mangrove Wood.

sn54.10:1.3.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ kimilaṃ āmantesi:
sn54.10:1.3.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Kimbila,

sn54.10:1.4.pli: “kathaṃ bhāvito nu kho, kimila, ānāpānassatisamādhi kathaṃ bahulīkato mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso”ti?
sn54.10:1.4.eng: “Kimbila, how is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?”

sn54.10:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā kimilo tuṇhī ahosi.
sn54.10:2.1.eng: When he said this, Kimbila kept silent.

sn54.10:2.3.pli: tatiyampi kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ kimilaṃ āmantesi:
sn54.10:2.3.eng: And for a third time, the Buddha said to him,

sn54.10:2.4.pli: “kathaṃ bhāvito nu kho, kimila, ānāpānassatisamādhi kathaṃ bahulīkato mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso”ti?
sn54.10:2.4.eng: “How is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?”

sn54.10:2.5.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā kimilo tuṇhī ahosi.
sn54.10:2.5.eng: And a second time and a third time Kimbila kept silent.

sn54.10:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn54.10:3.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

sn54.10:3.2.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

sn54.10:3.3.pli: Yaṃ bhagavā ānāpānassatisamādhiṃ bhāseyya, bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
sn54.10:3.3.eng: Let the Buddha speak on immersion due to mindfulness of breathing. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

sn54.10:4.1.eng: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn54.10:4.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

sn54.10:4.4.pli: “kathaṃ bhāvito ca, ānanda, ānāpānassatisamādhi kathaṃ bahulīkato mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso?
sn54.10:4.4.eng: “Ānanda, how is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?

sn54.10:4.5.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
sn54.10:4.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.

sn54.10:4.6.eng: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out. …

sn54.10:4.7.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’

sn54.10:4.8.pli: Evaṃ bhāvito kho, ānanda, ānāpānassatisamādhi evaṃ bahulīkato mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso.
sn54.10:4.8.eng: That’s how immersion due to mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.

sn54.10:5.1.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu dīghaṃ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṃ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
sn54.10:5.1.eng: There’s a time when a mendicant is breathing in heavily, and they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’

sn54.10:5.2.pli: rassaṃ vā assasanto ‘rassaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṃ vā passasanto ‘rassaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
sn54.10:5.2.eng: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’

sn54.10:5.3.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’

sn54.10:5.4.pli: ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati—
sn54.10:5.4.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’

sn54.10:5.5.pli: kāye kāyānupassī, ānanda, bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.10:5.5.eng: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.10:5.7.eng: Because the breath is a certain aspect of the body, I say.

sn54.10:5.8.pli: Tasmātihānanda, kāye kāyānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.10:5.8.eng: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.10:6.1.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu ‘pītippaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘pītippaṭisaṃvedī passasissāmī’ti sikkhati;
sn54.10:6.1.eng: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing rapture.’

sn54.10:6.2.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing bliss.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing bliss.’

sn54.10:6.3.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the the mental process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the the mental process.’

sn54.10:6.4.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the mental process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the mental process.’

sn54.10:6.5.pli: vedanāsu vedanānupassī, ānanda, bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.10:6.5.eng: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.10:6.7.pli: Vedanāññatarāhaṃ, ānanda, etaṃ vadāmi, yadidaṃ—assāsapassāsānaṃ sādhukaṃ manasikāraṃ.
sn54.10:6.7.eng: Because careful application of mind to the in-breaths and out-breaths is a certain aspect of feelings, I say.

sn54.10:6.8.pli: Tasmātihānanda, vedanāsu vedanānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.10:6.8.eng: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.10:7.1.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu ‘cittappaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘cittappaṭisaṃvedī passasissāmī’ti sikkhati;
sn54.10:7.1.eng: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mind.’

sn54.10:7.2.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in gladdening the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out gladdening the mind.’

sn54.10:7.3.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in immersing the mind in samādhi.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out immersing the mind in samādhi.’

sn54.10:7.4.pli: ‘vimocayaṃ cittaṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘vimocayaṃ cittaṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati—
sn54.10:7.4.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in freeing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out freeing the mind.’

sn54.10:7.5.pli: citte cittānupassī, ānanda, bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.10:7.5.eng: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.10:7.7.pli: Nāhaṃ, ānanda, muṭṭhassatissa asampajānassa ānāpānassatisamādhibhāvanaṃ vadāmi.
sn54.10:7.7.eng: Because there is no development of immersion due to mindfulness of breathing for someone who is unmindful and lacks awareness, I say.

sn54.10:7.8.pli: Tasmātihānanda, citte cittānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.10:7.8.eng: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.10:8.1.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu ‘aniccānupassī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati …pe…
sn54.10:8.1.eng: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing impermanence.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing impermanence.’

sn54.10:8.2.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing fading away.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing fading away.’

sn54.10:8.3.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing cessation.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing cessation.’

sn54.10:8.4.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’

sn54.10:8.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī, ānanda, bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.10:8.5.eng: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.10:8.6.pli: So yaṃ taṃ hoti abhijjhādomanassānaṃ pahānaṃ taṃ paññāya disvā sādhukaṃ ajjhupekkhitā hoti.
sn54.10:8.6.eng: Having seen with wisdom the giving up of covetousness and displeasure, they watch closely over with equanimity.

sn54.10:8.7.pli: Tasmātihānanda, dhammesu dhammānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.10:8.7.eng: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.10:9.1.eng: Suppose there was a large heap of sand at the crossroads.

sn54.10:9.2.pli: Puratthimāya cepi disāyaṃ āgaccheyya sakaṭaṃ vā ratho vā, upahanateva taṃ paṃsupuñjaṃ;
sn54.10:9.2.eng: And a cart or chariot were to come by from the east,

sn54.10:9.5.pli: dakkhiṇāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya sakaṭaṃ vā ratho vā, upahanateva taṃ paṃsupuñjaṃ.
sn54.10:9.5.eng: or south and destroy that heap of sand.

sn54.10:9.6.pli: Evameva kho, ānanda, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharantopi upahanateva pāpake akusale dhamme;
sn54.10:9.6.eng: In the same way, when a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body,

sn54.10:9.9.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharantopi upahanateva pāpake akusale dhamme”ti.
sn54.10:9.9.eng: or principles, they destroy bad, unskillful qualities.”
